The Legislature Of this State assembled at Dover,
on Tuesday and elected archibald Hamilton, Esq.
Speaker Samuel NJ. Harrington, Esq CIerk-and
Vincsnt Vandeuer Sergeant at.Arms. The Senate
did not organize until Wednesday afternoon. when
Col. Henry Whiteley was chosen Speaker-Henry
Stout, Esq. Clerk-and John Cats Sergeant. at.
Arms The Governors Message was to be deliv
cred yesterday.
DELAWARE LEGISLATURE.

ICEBERGS.-Tte ship Frederick Augustus.
Earle which arrived II Newport( r. /. )psssed off
Cape Horn. October, lOh, forty one large Islands
of Ice, several Of them supposed be eight nine
miles in lengih and very high--,he atmosphere was
exceedingly cold in the vicinity Of the Ice and the
Spray froze Immediately on The sails and rigging


PHILADELPHIA. Dec. 29th.-A graveyard short
distance OF the Permanen Bfidge, was violated
abou. two weeks ago. Three or four graves we're
opened and the bodies taken lherefrom. A
shocking spectacle was presented the following
morning. The graves were no, filled; the coffins
remained above ground, and the shrouds were srewn
about. They remained in this condition several
days, as the person who has the care Of The yard
wbs absent.


One Of the pilots on Wednesday morning picked
up man, il yawl, in the neghbourhood OF the
Point House. F,om the joint effects OF cold ard in
oxication, he was speechless; but by proper aten-
lion far restored 10 his senses to be able to
state that he belonged 10 the brig James Lawrence,
which is now lying in ,he neiehbourhood Of Reedy
Island land tina, he had been drifting about in the
river for the preceding thirty six hours. His hands
and fee, were severely frost bitten. He has been
sen, to the Hospital.


.Ne,o York, Dec. 27.


rHENxwMAYoR WIN. Psulding Esq. was yes.
terday elected mayor Of this city fer the year ensu-
ing. This gentleman was the predecessor, as he is
to be the SUCCESSOR of Mr. Hone.


Rochester, ". Tork. Dec. 13.-The doubts and
uncertainty which still mystify the Batavia affair,
give Increased interest and add fresh zeal 10 the
general inquiry Of " Where is Morgan 2" The
question is in the mouth Of the whole community.
1t is The all absorbing topic Of conversation and the
inquiry, like the school-boy's snow ball, acquires
strength and magnitude, the farther it is pursued.
As yet, nothing is known beyond the fact that Nor
gan is gone-but where, whether he be alsr or
dead We are unable TO say. Telegraph.


Philadelphia. Dec 23.-The question Of the au-
thorship Of the Wavery novels, was considered as
settled by the exposition Of affairs, consequent upon
the failure o Constable x Co. the publishers. Still,
however. there some no scepiical, notwith-
standing the life of Napoleon, avcwediy written By
Sir Walter Scott, is announced in the London pa
pers, as f om the pen of the author of Wavely On
Wednesday we saw letter unquestionsbly authen-
,icated IS coming from Sir Walter Scott and signed
" TIE .duthor Of Warerly." The writer, had at
first designed subscribing il with his proper name !;
WaHer was written, aud erased with stroke OF the
pen, but still eeible The letter is on the subject
Of the Lite OF Napoleon. Franklin Gazette.

BOSTON, DEC. ZJ
On Saturday last, Judge Story pronounced sen
trnce of death upon Charles MarchAnt and Win
SLOW Curtis, convicted Of the murder Of Captain Ed
ward Se.frdee. of the schooner Fairy, and Thomas
r. Jeokns his mate


When the Judge had concluded, Marchant a
bused The Judge, Jury and District Attorney in the
most impious and insulting language. Cults,
though not SO violent also evnced The depravity OF
his heart by his observations and we believe no
Court OF Justice in this country ever before witness
I'd such an exhibition Of hardened impenitence as
these miscrrants pI Iesented.


The sentence is to be executed on Thursday, the
Grs day Of February. Pat.

DRAWING
OF TIE

DED--O Wednesday evening last, MIR. JOSEPH Ro-
RINSON. Merchant, Of this Borough.

In our last paper we gave the letter OF The Vice
President TO the Speaker o the House Of Represent
s,ives. We this day publish the names Of the Com
mttee appointed investigate the subject to which
the letter refers The charge Of participation IN
the Mix contract, by Major Vandevenier, is MI
new neither 10 il now ior the first time that an allie
CATION hos appeared in the papers, thst Mr.. Calhoun
was acquainted with tina, circumstance. The fact
OF participation is admitted letter of Major Vsn-
devep,er, published in the Washington Gazette the
predecessor of the Telegraph, on the 22d OF April
1925 and the fact that his participation was with the
knowledge Of Mr.. Calhoun. and that the contract
with Mix wa. entered into without the usual notice
being given by public advertisements. was stated IN
the report Of the committee of the II OF Reps. upon
that subject, made at the close OF the session. and
published about that time. We shall take occasion
to republish the letter and report, with some OBJ
servatons on the subject, in our next. We cannot
however, refrain from The expression OF our regret
that the subject should have been presented to Con
gress at time when so much and such important
business is about to come before that body.


For the present, We will only observe that we
think there is something in Mr.. Calhoun's commu
nicaton to the House OF Representatives very oblec
lionable .. it is capable ofbeng SO construed how
ever intended, as to assign cause and origin ,e
this occurrence which entirely different from IT.
true cause and origin. ". Journal, Jan. l.
-----s<s 95JJd30 shs--

The Philadelphia Greek Committee, at meeting on
the 1s inst passed the following Resolution


Resofped unanimously, That the thanks Of this Commit
tee be presented Mr. WILLIAM POOLE Of Brandywine,
for his generous offers TO aid in the collection Of provs
for the distressed Greeks that he be requested to
continue his benevolent efforts ;-and that he be- and he
hereby s appointed Agent for thus purpose, for his neigh
borllood." Signed by order


MATHEW CAREY, Chairman.

Washington, January sd.-On Monday last, ac-
cordips to established usage on New Year day. the
Presidents house was open ior the reception OF Wis
tiers, when, Notwithstanding the day was extremely
cold the President received the congratulations OF
larger number than it is believed ever assembled
on any similar or other occasion, in the Executive
mansion: all the rooms, including the great eastern
room, as we'll as the large Hall were crowded to
excess, for several hours although there was con.
sant change Of the company, occasioned by the re


tirng Of some and the entrance OF others. The
foreign ministers generally were present with the
members Of their respective legations; all the Heads
of Departments, the members Of both Houses OF
Congress- the principal and other officers OF the Gov


crnment, civil, military, and naval. besides an i'm


mense number of strangers, amounting to several
thousands. The annualfnerchange OF sauta.ons
between the President, OF the United States and the
citizens, on the commencement oil The year, gives to
the day the peculiar character of Republican tes-
val the observance Of which, trust, will never be
discontinued. journal.

Washington, December 29.-The recent Conven-
,ion between tha United States and Great Britain.
putting an end TO the Commission under the Treaty
Of Ghent for adudcating compensation to the losers
of property carried away from the United States after
the close OF the late war, has been confirmed by the
Senate Of the United States, and, having been sub.
nitted to that body by the Presidents will doubtless be
ratified by him. BY ths, Convention SPECIFIC sum
/. awarded Tor she satisfaction Of all the claims which
i, to be distributed amongst them by the authority
Of the Government of the United Ststes-Intel.

full articles.article:
In our last paper we gave the letter OF The Vice
President TO the Speaker o the House Of Represent
s,ives. We this day publish the names Of the Com
mttee appointed investigate the subject to which
the letter refers The charge Of participation IN
the Mix contract, by Major Vandevenier, is MI
new neither 10 il now ior the first time that an allie
CATION hos appeared in the papers, thst Mr.. Calhoun
was acquainted with tina, circumstance. The fact
OF participation is admitted letter of Major Vsn-
devep,er, published in the Washington Gazette the
predecessor of the Telegraph, on the 22d OF April
1925 and the fact that his participation was with the
knowledge Of Mr.. Calhoun. and that the contract
with Mix wa. entered into without the usual notice
being given by public advertisements. was stated IN
the report Of the committee of the II OF Reps. upon
that subject, made at the close OF the session. and
published about that time. We shall take occasion
to republish the letter and report, with some OBJ
servatons on the subject, in our next. We cannot
however, refrain from The expression OF our regret
that the subject should have been presented to Con
gress at time when so much and such important
business is about to come before that body.


For the present, We will only observe that we
think there is something in Mr.. Calhoun's commu
nicaton to the House OF Representatives very oblec
lionable .. it is capable ofbeng SO construed how
ever intended, as to assign cause and origin ,e
this occurrence which entirely different from IT.
true cause and origin. ". Journal, Jan. l.

The Philadelphia Greek Committee, at meeting on
the 1s inst passed the following Resolution


Resofped unanimously, That the thanks Of this Commit
tee be presented Mr. WILLIAM POOLE Of Brandywine,
for his generous offers TO aid in the collection Of provs
for the distressed Greeks that he be requested to
continue his benevolent efforts ;-and that he be- and he
hereby s appointed Agent for thus purpose, for his neigh
borllood." Signed by order


MATHEW CAREY, Chairman.

Washington, January sd.-On Monday last, ac-
cordips to established usage on New Year day. the
Presidents house was open ior the reception OF Wis
tiers, when, Notwithstanding the day was extremely
cold the President received the congratulations OF
larger number than it is believed ever assembled
on any similar or other occasion, in the Executive
mansion: all the rooms, including the great eastern
room, as we'll as the large Hall were crowded to
excess, for several hours although there was con.
sant change Of the company, occasioned by the re


tirng Of some and the entrance OF others. The
foreign ministers generally were present with the
members Of their respective legations; all the Heads
of Departments, the members Of both Houses OF
Congress- the principal and other officers OF the Gov


crnment, civil, military, and naval. besides an i'm


mense number of strangers, amounting to several
thousands. The annualfnerchange OF sauta.ons
between the President, OF the United States and the
citizens, on the commencement oil The year, gives to
the day the peculiar character of Republican tes-
val the observance Of which, trust, will never be
discontinued. journal.

Washington, December 29.-The recent Conven-
,ion between tha United States and Great Britain.
putting an end TO the Commission under the Treaty
Of Ghent for adudcating compensation to the losers
of property carried away from the United States after
the close OF the late war, has been confirmed by the
Senate Of the United States, and, having been sub.
nitted to that body by the Presidents will doubtless be
ratified by him. BY ths, Convention SPECIFIC sum
/. awarded Tor she satisfaction Of all the claims which
i, to be distributed amongst them by the authority
Of the Government of the United Ststes-Intel.
